Created an attachment (id=1399)
debug on/off plugin
In 2.0 I got only a dialog with a warning. See attachment. The jar is generated.

In fact the warning is not important. I tried in 1.0 and the
NullPointerException was thrown in jdt.ui. Here is the stack trace:
Log: Thu Jun 13 14:44:46 EDT 2002
4 org.eclipse.jdt.ui 566 Creation of JAR failed
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.lang.String.<init>(Unknown Source)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.jarpackager.JarFileExportOperation.buildJavaToClassMap(JarFileExportOperation.java:147)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.jarpackager.JarFileExportOperation.filesOnClasspath(JarFileExportOperation.java:350)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.jarpackager.JarFileExportOperation.exportElement(JarFileExportOperation.java:270)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.jarpackager.JarFileExportOperation.exportSelectedElements(JarFileExportOperation.java:317)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.jarpackager.JarFileExportOperation.singleRun(JarFileExportOperation.java:614)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.jarpackager.JarFileExportOperation.run(JarFileExportOperation.java:529)
	at
org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:98)

This is fixed in 2.0. A warning is issued because a map could not be built
without the source attribute. Do we really need a warning? I think the message
should explain to the user why the source attribute is important. I don't see
why we need it in order to export a .class file into a jar. I would expect this
warning to disappear. It you want to package a product, you might not include
the debug attributes. And then a warning is confusing, because you actually want
to export .class files without debug attributes into a jar file.
Move to JDT/UI for comments.

But, is there actually a class file in the jar?
In Eclipse-1 (WSAD-4.03) I got a jar and warning,
but no class file in the jar.

In 2.0 you get the class in the jar and this is why I don't like the warning
message. It doesn't add anything for the user. It is even worse. It is confusing
the user. Is my jar valid? Is my jar usable? These can the questions you ask
yourself when you see this message.
I would say the warning message should be either clearer or removed.

Agreed.

In fact, there should be no warning since having no sourcefile
name is JUST FINE for a nondebug compilation.  There is nothing
wrong (but the Eclipse code - so dont falg to the user that the
Eclipse code used to be wrong).

What about eclipse-1.0?  Personally, I dont think a fixpack is needed.

The JAR exporter is source based as you can see in the selection dialog i.e. you
select packages and CUs (neither single classes nor class files). The (source
name) debug attribute is used to find out which class files belong to a selected
CU. This is needed because currently there's no JDT Core API to get the class
files (or it's names) for a given CU (see bug 6584).

If you simply want to export .class files then you can use the ZIP exporter on
the output location.

Did you read the whole warning? It only informs the user about the fact that
eventually more than the selected files has been put into the JAR e.g. if your
package contained 1000 CUs and you exported one CU of it the JAR would still
contain all the 1000 class files because the exporter couldn't find out which
ones belonged to the CU. I think this is useful info for the user. However since
it really is only an info I changed the warning to be an info only (with
corresponding icon).

Suggest to close the PR.

Note: The debug info generation can be configured via preferences in 2.0
Change of message from warning to info released for 2.1
